title: Dessert Plate, "Kremlin Service", ca. 1830
markings: On underside, underglaze blue: elaborate "H", crowned monogram of Nicholas I, 1825-1855
provenance: 2005: acquired by Museum (from A la Vieille Russie Inc.)
creditline: Museum purchase from General Acquisitions Endowment Fund
description: Circular form, the center decorated with black, double-headed imperial eagle on green ground within a circular band of Cyrillic lettering (translation: Nicholas the Emperor and Ruler of All the Russias), surrounded by decoration of red flowers in gilded lozenges alternating with green foliate forms; the rim with green and blue foliage intertwined with black scrollwork on gilded ground.
justification:
From the Acquisition Justification:
"This plate is a very fine example of Russian Imperial porcelain. This example was produced for the Kremlin service. The service was ordered by Nicholas I to the designs of Professor Th. Solntsev who held an important position in the Imperial sponsored movement of rediscovering and reinterpreting of old Russian forms.&nbsp; Solntsev drew upon 17th century metalwork as the model for this service, making use in particular of a gold dish made in 1667 for the Tsarina Natalia Kirilovna (see Russian Enamels, XI-XIX Centuries, Moscow, 1974, pl. 61). The Grand Kremlin Palace was built by the architect K.A. Thon (1794-1881), with a brief from the Tsar to create a building in the Russian style showing also the influence of Byzantium.&nbsp; It was for this new-Russian setting that the Kremlin service was designed. The plate has a specifically Russian design featuring the Imperial eagle surrounded by a Cyrillic inscription (translation: Nicholas the Emperor and Ruler of All the Russias) on a richly decorated surface."

tombstone.epitaph: Dessert Plate, "Kremlin Service", ca. 1830.Gilt and glazed porcelain. Museum purchase from General Acquisitions Endowment Fund. 2005-6-1.
